title: Profits up as JP Morgan slashes costs
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 14, 2015, 20:07 BST - UK Markets closed Profits up as JP Morgan slashes costs By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 4 hours ago Print 
But revenues fell across the board as income from mortgage banking and trading slumped 
US investment bank JP Morgan’s profits increased in the second quarter of the year as cost-cutting measures outweighed a fall in revenues. 
The lending giant's sales fell 3pc to $24.5bn (£15.7bn) in the three-month period, down from $25.3bn in the second quarter of 2014. 
But the bank managed to shave 6pc off costs, which boosted profits by 5pc to $6.3bn. 
Lower legal bills and falling compensation costs gave JP Morgan a substantial boost, and suggest that it's moving beyond some of the more damaging legacies of the boom years and the financial crisis. 
The bank has also axed 6,000 staff, which contributed to the $500m of cost savings generated in the first half of the year. This puts JP Morgan on track to achieve its target of $2bn of annual cost savings by 2017. 
Almost every part of JP Morgan's business suffered a slump in revenues in the second quarter. Mortgage banking income plunged by just over one-fifth, while the wider consumer and business banking division suffered an 8pc decline in revenues. The bank blamed the poor performance on compressed spreads and squeezed interest income. 
But the trading arm of JP Morgan's investment bank was also badly hit, as lower volumes and volatile market conditions sent revenues down by 10pc year-on-year. 
The dismal outcome dashed hopes that a recent rebound in fixed income trading in the first quarter might be sustained. 
However, the overall investment banking division performed relatively well, reporitng a 4pc increase in sales, as high demand for advisory work on deals and an increase in debt issuasnce by businesses offset poor trading elsewhere. 
Sales at the asset management division rose 6pc, but costs jumped by 17pc and credit losses grew, driving profits down by 21pc to $451m. 
Analysts praised the results as a sign that the bank’s cost-cutting drive is paying off. 
“Despite weak net interest income and fixed income, and weaker than expected currency and commodities results, we expect the shares to react favourably given strong corporate and investment banking results, continued efficiency progress, and healthy capital build,” said Nomura’s Steven Chubak. 
JP Morgan's shares rose 1.55pc on the results to $68.09.
